input:
# Number of models for which details are described in this input file
1
# Restart from previous (pickled) population?
False
#Series of epsilons. (Comma-delimited list) #If the length of the epsilon series is one and you have only one model #you are effectively doing abc Rejection
# Automatic epsilon schedule. Provide a vector of final epsilons and the alpha (defaults to 0.9)
1 0.9
# Particles 500
# Beta is the number of times to simulate each sampled parameter set. # This is only Ô¨Åapplicable for models simulated using SDE.
1
# Internal timestep for solver. # Make this small for a stiff model.
1
# rtol and atol can be specified here. # If the model is stiff then setting these to small # might help the simulation to run. # Only applicable for models simulated using ODE.
1e-6 1e-6
#User-supplied data.
# times: For abc-SMC, times must be a whitespace delimited list starting with 0. # For simulation only the first and last timepoints are used. # To make a synthetic data set give a whitespace delimited list of timepoints at which data points are required.
0 0.5 1 2 4 8
# variables: For abc-SMC, whitespace delimited lists of concentrations (ODE or SDE) or molecule numbers (Gillespie). # Denote your data as variable1, variable2, ..., variableN. # For simulation or synthetic data sets these data are ignored. # See fitting instruction below if the dimensionality of your data sets differ from the dimensionality of your model.
20.002 7.688 3.983 2.423 1.189 0.984 20 11.7106 9.8755 8.95735 8.02924 5.08208 20 9.36882 6.55783 4.90692 4.70811 4.12581 80 24.8 21.3 16.8 10 5 80 61.8 59 54.8 50.3 56 54.4545 44.9846 36.3091 40.6811 34.1147 26.751 51.8266 48.2462 44.6643 45.7958 49.2378 46.5273 32.2462 12.428 7.60979 5.09091 2.78601 1.9021
Fit model-OneProcess-step2-2k.xml
# type: the method used to simulate your model. ODE, SDE or Gillespie. Gillespie
# Fitting information. If fit is None, all species in the model are fitted to the data in the order they are listed in the model. # Otherwise, give a whitespace delimited list of fitting instrictions the same length as the dimensions of your data. # Use speciesN to denote the Nth species in your model. Simple arithmatic operations can be performed on the species from your model. # For example, to fit the sum of the first two species in your model to your first variable, write fit: species1+species2 None
# Priors: # one of # constant, value # uniform, lower, upper # gaussian, mean, variance
constant 1.0 latent 1 0 latent 1 0 constant 700 constant 700 constant 700 constant 2800 constant 2800 constant 1906.0 constant 1814 constant 1128.7 latent 1 0 latent 1 0 latent 1 0 latent 1 0 latent 1 1 latent 1 1 latent 1 1 latent 1 0 latent 1 0 latent 1 0 latent 1 0 latent 1 0 latent 1 0 latent 1 0 latent 1 0 latent 1 0 latent 1 0 hierarchical -4 4 0.5 1 hierarchical -4 4 0.5 1 hivar 0.05 0.9
constant 0.0 constant 700.0 constant 700.0 constant 700.0 constant 0.0 constant 700.0 constant 700.0 constant 0.0 constant 700.0 constant 2800 constant 0.0 constant 2800 constant 2800 constant 0.0 constant 2800 constant 1906 constant 0.0 constant 1906 constant 1814 constant 0.0 constant 1814 constant 1128.7 constant 0.0 constant 1128.7 constant 2800 constant 0.0 constant 700 constant 700 constant 0.0 constant 0.0
